citation.article-title: Characterization of marine luminous bacteria isolated off the coast of China and description of Vibrio orientalis sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Vibrio orientalis sp. nov.
Vibrio orientalis (L. adj. orientalis, of or belonging to the Orient)

The phenotypic properties of strains 715-719 (Table 1) as well as those of strains representative of all of the species of Vibrio and Photobacterium listed by Baumann et al. [7] were submitted to a numerical analysis.
The results (not shown) indicated that these isolates were distinct and differed from the species of these two genera by 9-32 phenotypic properties.
Four additional species of Vibrio have recently been described [13,16,17,20].

Although characterized by a different and somewhat more limited methodology than the one used in our studies, the results, nevertheless, clearly indicate that the species are phenotypically distinct from V. orientalis.
An electron microscopic examination of strain 717, grown on liquid or solid medium, revealed the presence of a single, sheathed polar flagellum (Fig. 2).
The G+C contents of the DNA of strain 715, 717, and 719 were 45.8, 45.4, and 45.3 moles %, respectively.
All of these results indicate that the cluster consisting of strains 715-719 was a new species of Vibrio, which we have designated as V. orientalis sp. nov.
Strain 717 has been designated as the type strain and deposited in the American Type Culture Collection as ATCC 33934.

V. orientalis is the only described luminous species of Vibrio that is able to accumulate poly-β-hydroxybutyrate as an intracellular reserve product and to utilize DL-β-hydroxybutyrate, putrescine, and spermine as sole or principal sources of carbon and energy.

Additional diagnostic traits are the presence of an amylase, an arginine dihydrolase system, growth at 4 °C but not at 40 °C and the ability to utilize sucrose and cellobiose but not glucuronate, α-ketoglutarate, and γ-aminobutyrate as sole or principal sources of carbon and energy.
This combination of properties distinguishes V. orientalis from species of Vibrio and Photobacterium by 6-I0 traits.
Using the antiserum to the SOD from V. alginolyticus 90, V. splendidus biotype II 2, V. fischeri 61, and V. cholerae M13 [1], we have determined the ImDs of strains 715, 716, and 717.
The combined results for all three strains (expressed as the mean ± standard deviation) are 6.4 ± 0.1, 23.5 ± 0.2, 26.0 ± 0.8, and 59 ± 0.4 ImD units, respectively.

A three-dimensional representation of the results, which includes only those species and strains of Vibrio with an SOD similar to the enzyme from V. orientalis, is presented in Fig. 3. (This figure is a portion of the larger Fig. 3 in reference [1], which includes many additional strains of Vibrio.) On the basis of its SOD, V. orientalis is related to the relatively large group of primarily marine species of Vibrio, which includes such common species as V. harveyi, V. alginolyticus, and V. parahaemolyticus.
Its nearest neighbor is strain 77; both V. orientalis and strain 77 have an arginine dihydrolase system.
